message_1: On the period-doubling route to chaos, a logistic map is defined as x_n+1 = r*x_n*(1-x_n), where x_0 = 0.2 and r = 3.5. Compute the first ten iterates of this map and plot them on a graph. What is the first value of r at which the logistic map becomes chaotic?
message_2:
To compute the first ten iterates of the logistic map with x_0 = 0.2 and r = 3.5, we can use the formula x_n+1 = r*x_n*(1-x_n) iteratively:

x_1 = 3.5 * 0.2 * (1 - 0.2) = 0.56
x_2 = 3.5 * 0.56 * (1 - 0.56) ≈ 0.8624
x_3 = 3.5 * 0.8624 * (1 - 0.8624) ≈ 0.4165
x_4 = 3.5 * 0.4165 * (1 - 0.4165) ≈ 0.8498
x_5 = 3.5 * 0.8498 * (1 - 0.8498) ≈ 0.4446
x_6 = 3.5 * 0.4446 * (1 - 0.4446) ≈ 0.8633
x_7 = 3.5 * 0.8633 * (1 - 0.8633) ≈ 0.4119
x_8 = 3.5 * 0.4119 * (1 - 0.4119) ≈ 0.8459
x_9 = 3.5 * 0.8459 * (1 - 0.8459) ≈ 0.4573
x_10 = 3.5 * 0.4573 * (1 - 0.4573) ≈ 0.8672

To plot these values on a graph, you can use any graphing software or tool and plot the points (1, 0.56), (2, 0.8624), (3, 0.4165), (4, 0.8498), (5, 0.4446), (6, 0.8633), (7, 0.4119), (8, 0.8459), (9, 0.4573), and (10, 0.8672).

The first value of r at which the logistic map becomes chaotic is approximately r ≈ 3.57. This is known as the onset of chaos, and it occurs at the Feigenbaum point. Beyond this value, the behavior of the logistic map becomes increasingly complex and unpredictable.
